title: Are hackers normal programmers, or do they learn special techniques? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are many varieties of "hackers" and that's ignoring the original use, that describe people like Richard Stallman, who have nothing to do with what "normal" people now call hackers. Anyway, ignoring that digression, there are hackers that know almost nothing about programming except how to run preprogrammed attacks. These are called "script kiddies" and the preprogrammed attacks they run are "scripts". There are also hackers who write malware. Many of them are essentially garden variety programmers. They write code that uses "exploits", bits of code that take advantage of some weakness in the system being attacked to allow the program to get access it wouldn't normally have. There are also hackers that look for new exploits. There is an equivalent for them called "penetration testers". These kind of hackers do have techniques that are slightly different from normal programming, although much of what they is akin to debugging, finding out why a program breaks, although the goal is to use that to find a way past security not to fix it. There are many others, but that should give you a rough idea that hopefully answers your question.

When I started programming we would call hackers “ibm systems programmer or ibm systems engineer “ Yes you did take extra courses to learn about the internals of the IBM os and how to trouble shoot problems that customers would have and how to patch and fix the os. To day you would study the Linux os and windows OS by taking courses or reading books that deal with writing drivers and os internals and you would customize linux, since its open source, you can take it apart and learn how it works internally, That would be “white hat hacking” doing legit work for customers or yourself. “Black had hacking” is usually for a criminal purpose. There is extensive documentation on the internals of linux on many web sites and books, Microsoft publishes extensive documentation on its os and classes on its web site. Microsoft publishes updates to fix bugs in its software, oftern a hacker will learn about bugs from microsoft updates or from security web sites, then try to exploit these bugs for good or bad purposes.

Hacker is a very general term that includes government Information Security analysts (infoSec) working for the CIA, NSA, FBI, and any other three-letter acronym you might think, the Russian threat to undermine the democratic process, the Anonymous movement, all the way to the kid with his android cellphone that hacks his school information system and changes the C to an A. Hackers work alone or in groups, think “Mr. Robot”. Hackers like any other sub-group of the information world, as is noted in other posts, have the same qualities as most information specialists. They can be good or bad, intelligent or the other thing, lazy or driven. The two qualities, in my opinion, that make or break a good hacker are the curiosity to explore and the ingenuity to think outside the box. I will give an honorable mention to the will to succeed where others have failed. I say this because hacker types always want the credit for the hack. It’s the abacus of the hackers reward system. The hacker designation is not their core values, but the way they see how the hardware, softare, human interface, policies, procedures, and other component of the information world we live in. They are the demolition experts and safety engineers of the computer world. They see the columns and cracks and holes in the skycraper to determine where the weeknesses can be found and then put in the RDX and bring it to the ground. These are Blackhats, or unethical hackers (don’t get hung up on morality). Blackhat’rs have a purpose and good or bad, eventually clean up the crappy information systems in the world. Whitehats, or ethical hackers, are the safety engineers. They take the new plans and by studying the blue-prints(computer code, hardware, interfaces, etc) and plug any gaps in security that were missed prior to construction. Penetration testers are also included in this category and they do the security remodelling. In systems already deployed and in the world today, Pen-testers go in with their blackhat bag of goodies and ethically hack, crack, crash, disable, and “steal” from their employers to find all the vulnerabilities that a true Blackhat would find and use to compromise the trust of the employer and drain the financial resources of the company. As far as techniques and skills, the best hackers have a solid mastery of core languages, C, C++, and base code of the machines they are trying to compromise. As languages become more transparent and higher fuctioning, the knowledge of lower level languages becomes necessary when flaws in the operation of hardware components is required and the fundamental operation of the physical layer needs to be accessed(think computer controlled security access doors). Using machine code, the fundamental rules of operation can be altered like open, close, lock, jam, lock in open position. Languages and systems are easy to learn. Any good linguist can pick up a new language or dialect, just as any good hacker can pick up Php or Python and hack using the rules of that language. Anyone can hack, but only the gifted can walk through walls, be invisible, and get in and out before anyone knows they are there.

The hack is the end, anything in between is the thrill. Hacking is basically a special purpose mental exercise which can be learned by anyone (with or without formal education) with a sound foundation in programming, networking, computing, electronics, or combination of two or more of these disciplines. I included the words “special purpose” because no one knows everything but people can be really good in their areas of interests. Programming is not a prerequisite but a strong passion for new ideas and things is. There is nothing special about these techniques unless you’re the original proponent of the technique. The rest are mere innovators implementing it in different areas of disciplines and scenarios. Failure is routine and success is rare and only a few can claim being the first to do it. That is why you shouldn’t give a damn where your class or skill level lie. People who call others “kiddies” are basically insecure people who don’t understand how things work in real life. Their idols, these so-called experts that they embrace and follow were once beginners too. Never underestimate or downplay other people’s skills or interests, not even a kid. Because all that is required to qualify is to be in the zone, for a long time. The tools, the mentors, and the knowledge are available for free to everyone in the Internet.

You can tell the difference between a hacker and a programmer when they run into a bug. The normal programmer will do whatever they can to fix or mitigate the bug so they can run the program and move on. The hacker will study how the bug works to see if they can exploit it to do something meaningful (like disclose data that is supposed to be hidden, or run code that is not supposed to run). Knowing how to exploit bugs is the “special technique” they learn and you can learn more about them by googling the attack names: buffer overflowstack overflowdouble freeformat string attackXSS/CSRFlocal/remote file inclusionSQL injectionAnd many others.

response.answer_text: Most programmers are not hackers, because they paste code modules together in a manner that validates functional tests, and even if they add some extra code and test cases for security/performance/extensibility, this is secondary. The programming approach of a hacker is all about maintaining complete control; every data input is untrusted and every system call’s documented error conditions are handled—a hacker will go into the weeds, questioning if a compiler has been validated to emit the proper machine language code, and will produce verification tests for things which a “normal programmer” will simply assume. Naturally if somebody were to interest a great hacker into examining code she did not create herself, she will scrutinize it for undocumented “features” that may be useful to perform operations unthought of by the initial programmer. So if a hacker were doing programming, you can rest assured that instead of simply using open source components, the hacker would validate that all dependencies, down to the last bit of code included, was free of known vulnerabilities. We need more hackers. Good ones. Ethical ones. Most code has flaws that are obvious to a hacker. Hackers are not normal programmers. The special technique of questioning and validating assumptions is what sets us apart.

They learn special techniques. In fact, many can't program much at all. Most aspects of hacking are not about programming. They are about understanding how computers and networks work in the real world, where people make mistakes that can be exploited, and how to use the tools that find and exploit those mistakes. Some people do need to program to make the tools, but it's not that many. Most hackers do eventually learn mediocre Python just from being around it so much. At many major tech companies, Security Engineer is a separate job role from Software Engineer. For some of these roles programming is not required at all.

Hackers learn the same general programming skills as a regular programmer. The difference comes in the application of those skills. Generally programmers are building something up, (a website, infrastructure, operating systems, etc…), a hacker is attempting to exploit what others programmers have built. The hackers programming skills come into play when writing exploits or modifying exploits that someone else has built. The knowledge also comes in handy when viewing the code you want to exploit because you will have at least some knowledge on how code works. Hackers may not be as well versed in programming as someone who does it full time because a hacker may only need to know some scripting to get by. Programming is only one of the skills that hackers learn. Hackers will have a lot of knowledge of other aspects of tech, like networking architecture and setups.

There is a common misconception that anyone who understands computers is a “programmer”. A programmer is someone who writes or maintains software or scripts. The pc repair guy may understand hardware and know what part you need to replace, but he isn’t a “programmer”. A hacker studies security flaws and knows how to get around computer security. It doesn’t have to be technically challenging, the biggest security risk is the user, either from being tricked, manipulated, or making a dumb mistake. Most of “hacking” is psychological, some is understanding networks, and the last part is running other peoples scripts and being able to manipulate code.

In my mind there are two camps of hackers: The no deep knowledge hackers that take advantage of tools and code written by others. They often don’t need to know much they just run what they get. I have heard the rumor that in many eastern European countries you can find hack code listed in magazines sold at the corner stores. (If any Eastern Europeans read this I would love your comments on the rumor.)The programmer hacker who is a normal programmer who goes deeper under-the-hood and works at really understanding the underlying dynamics of the OSs and the hardareware. They also often understand the details of net protocols and routers. They go to things like ShmooCon 2018 - ShmooCon where they can hear lectures from people who have done deep forensic dissections of browser code and the like.

I would like to add to the answer that there are three types of hackers, white hat, black hat and grey hat hackers, black hat illegally manipulate vulnerabilities in systems to hurt, steel, or acquire other data. White hat hackers work for the federal government, in hacking into other countries systems, and or securing the computers of the federal government. Grey hat hackers hack for a different purpose, these will hack into computer systems then tell the owners of that system how they hacked in and how to better secure their systems. These typically end up getting hired by companies or by the federal government.

There are some hackers know as script kiddies that know very little of how the code they are injecting or exploiting actually works or why it works. Those that properly know how to hack white hat or black, general are software engineers. It only makes sense to have knowledge of how to build a program up to properly modify or tear it down, most exploits are custom programs or scripts that interact with the application being targeted so if one did not know how to program there would be no logical way for them to create the exploit to begin with. I would say you need more knowledge to penetrate security and bugs than a general engineer as you need to fully understand how the bug, gap, loop, or whatever you are attacking works to manipulate it to do what you want and not just how to patch it like a standard engineer would.

Rather than going into technicalities I will provide the answer analogically and in a very simple manner. It goes like this - Hacking can be considered as “breaking” something, where as programming as “creating” something. Now, you can break things without knowing how they were made/created. But if you know how that “something” was made/created, you might know/learn the disadvantages of the way it is created (let's say flaws/vulnerabilities). Which ultimately you can use to break “something”. Further simplifying : It's not necessary that hackers are programmers, but knowledge of programming definitely makes a hacker’s life easy (generally speaking). Consider it as another bullet point in skills list on hacker's resume. Cheers!
